bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, June 29, 1924

div1.p: Connor describes an unknown fever in Dutch Guiana. He discusses the prevalence of Aedes stegomyia and the types of water storage used in the area.

June 29 1924.
My dear Doctor Carter;
div1.p:
Your last letter received a few days ago. I am
truly pleased that my article “Suggestions for developing a Campaign to
control yellow Fever” met with your approval. You did indeed pay me a high
a fine compliment when you say that it improved on second reading.

Doctor Pothier and my self have about concluded our
mission in Dutch Guiana and will leave here to-morrow for Cayenne. We have
not found yellow fever or Weil's disease but there are a group of cases in
which jaundice is a promient symptom which is not easily explained in
every case. The cases which we are seeing and have seen since our arrival
are the last of an epidemic which seems to have started in November last.
The greater number of cases are seen in children from 5 to 10 years, some
are sick enough to go to bed while others keep moving around, some clear up in
a few days while others last tp 15 days. The mortality is nil in the children
but a death is occassionally seen in adults.

We have seen some of these cases, both children and
adults, and the only suggestion of y.f. is the jaundice. The one autopsy
in an adult, dying in the eight day of illness, show no y.f. lesions either
macroscopically or microscopically. The condition suggests a study and

In recent years great numbers of Javaneses have
been introduced into the Colony and it is not improbable that they
have brought with them a Spirochaetosis which is said to be rather
prevalent in Java. Dengue fever is known and recognized here. No case
of relapsing has as yet been found in the Colony. Bilharzia Mansoni is
a common occurrence some 40 to 50 cases being detected each year. These
cases are for the most part picked up in the routine examination of
faces from dispensary and hospital patients.

There is for intents and purposes a 100% aedes
stegomyia house infestation and this means more mosquitos in Paramaribo
than the same percentage means for Georgetown as in the latter place
an effort has been made to reduce this species while in Paramaribo no
attempt has been made.

The class of recptacles used for stowing the
domestic water supply consists of aljibes, surface cisterns, indoor tanks
barrels and smaller containers. There would be no problem in the work
of reducing the aedes stegomyia here as the people are anxious that it be

The following top-minnows abound here and have been
proven in our experiments made here to be voracious consumers of
mosquito larvae:
a. Acanthophacelus Reticulatus. Peters.
b. " " Bifurcans Eig.
c. Poecilia vivapara.

The cultures of leptospira given Dr. Pothier by Doctor
Noguchi became contaminated and were lost to us. They were alright
when we left Georgetown but mold contamination is the bug-bear in
this hot moist climate. Our clothes, trunks, leather goods were well
on the way to destruction whenbefore we realized what was happening. The
same thing happens in Buenaventura.

The alarming increase in filariasis in Paramaribo is
worrying the Government. It seems that over half the population has
elephantiasis and it is known that nearly 60% of the poor people are in-
fected altho many of them show no symptoms. All classes of people
are carrying the parasites in their blood stream. In Georgetown we saw

Malaria is not prevalent in Paramaribo but in
the other coast towns and in the Indian villages it is a scourge.
Here in the city the principal carrier appears to be the A. Tarsi-
maculata while elsehwere it is the Agrytarsis. The only anopheline
breeding places that I have found inn Paramaribo have been on the
fringe of the city.

I have not found to date that the aedes aegypti
breeding outside of containers. At Moengo a breeding place has been
found in a scooped-out rock near a French Deportee's shack.

We are looking forward with great interest to our
visit to French Guiana. The reports that have reached us as well
as our inspection of the penal colonies for St. Luarent and St Jean
would indicate that the French Authorities have undertaken work
looking to the mentionreduction of the aedes aegypti.
